title: Why does Gragas have a 73% ban rate? Is LCS influence that strong? o_O
body:

Personally I don't like banning champs who are far less popular in soloque than in the LCS. I think Grag and Sej are two of the best examples of this right now.

IMO they're not worth banning because your chance of running into a Sej main or a Gragas main who has a high mastery of their champion is extraordinarily low. I'd always prefer to ban out champs who have high playerbases and are strong at the same time.

 I feel that the 3 most impact-full bans at the moment are Zed, LB and Kat in no particular order. All of these champions have a high number of mains playing them in soloque and are at least in my opinion far more broken than any other champs.

Honestly? Gragas doesn't need to be mastered to be used in SoloQ. His entire kit has pretty high bases, a slow, two displacements, damage reduction, passive heal when using an ability every few seconds, and his W does % of health damage, allowing him to be a threat at all times of the game with or without AP.

The same thing happened with Yasuo because his WW and dashing was and still is super annoying. LB is still banned a lot and she's more annoying than she is dominant in terms of winning games. Kalista is banned a ton too because of how hard she is to catch and her ults. having a lot of disruption. However, there are ADCs like Jinx with 4% higher winrate which are banned 10x less. The more predictable a champion's kit, the less they will be banned in general. The highest banned champs tend to have a lot of outplay potential even if they are not objectively strongest.

I believe gragas to be a fairly strong champion, but in no way do i see him as an overpowered champion.
This is especially true in lower elo like silver. Gragas isn't really that scary in the hands of an average player, yet people still ban him just because he was popular in LCS.
Personally right now, in solo play, i always lean my bans on what is overpowered right now, (not who everyone wants me to ban)
At the moment that means most of the cinderhulk tanks. I find that the tanky champions right now are becoming very unkillable faster than they should be. Champions who scale on health are especially overpowered right now, volibear especially. (Im really suprised i haven't seen shen jungle come back yet.) 

Its always been this way though. A few years ago, people looked at skarner like he was garbage, dont touch that guy, he is useless.
Then he got played in the LCS and literally even though he had no buffs made, everyone started banning him. "Skarner is OP".

He's actually almost undeniably overpowered (and his banrate is not only due to LCS), but it's most likely due to Cinderhulk being broken than the champion itself (he also got buffed along with the release of Cinderhulk, which made the whole even more OP). He is also actually quite easy to use, and even if he wasn't he would still be overpowered, because low elo is not to be considered in balance matters. If stuff were to be balanced around low elo, it would seriously mess up competitive and high elo gameplay, which is generally not good, since lower elo players should strive to improve as much as they can, while the game should not evolve around them being bad. Each player is also supposed to naturally improve over time. Lastly, it is extremely hard to balance around low elo because of the huge variance in skill level down there. While in higher elo players are usually "the best" and can use each of their favorite champions at near-maximum potential, while low elo is much more differentiated.

Also, I really can't see how Voli is overpowered. Sure, he has health scaling and that improves A LITTLE (not much actually, especially given the fact Voli was really weak pre Cinderhulk already), but his array of disables is actually quite limited. What he offers that other tanks don't is more damage, which is not really necessary since pretty much every tank can do a crapload of damage nowadays thanks to Cinderhulk. This means highly disruptive thanks like Sej, Grag and Zac are great because while their damage and tankiness were OK before, now they get MORE tankiness and MORE damage for a very low price. Other tanks like Shyv and Hecarims who go tankier lack CC (well, Hec has that but definitely not as much), but are awesome early duelists and do A LOT of damage overall. Voli stands in the middle, he's nothing special. He lacks the damage to be as good as the toplane tanks, he lacks the CC to be as good as the jungle tanks.

About Skarner, you're not quite right. He was mostly a SoloQ pick all along and was outclassed by the early aggro junglers in the LCS. He was picked whenever the others were banned but was really not that popular in competitive play at all. In SoloQ he was a monster though, and it was due to his second rework, which was indeed a much needed buff. He got some slight nerfs the patch afterwards and he was never heard of again. My feeling is that his lack of mobility and good damage make him good only when his numbers are broken. His CC is outclassed I guess.

As for skarner, im talking about two seasons ago. He was played in the LCS (successfully so) and everyone went bonkers the next few weeks over skarner. Im talking original skarner, pre-rework.
As skarner stands right now, he definitely isnt one of the STRONGEST junglers in the game, but he is far from useless.
A few days ago i played skarner and i had the most damage on my team. I was full tank skarner, the only offensive item i had was an iceborn gauntlet. And i wasn't fed either. Considering that he can put out so much easy damage in a teamfight, peel the shit out of people, and supress a single enemy, i would say he can easily be put to good use in the right team comp.

If something is played in the LCS and has a decent winrate then it generally means the champion is in a good spot. If you have a decent concept of how to play that champion it only makes sense to start playing it yourself if you want to climb. 

It is really unlikely that someone would have a 50%+ ban rate just because someone picked it in the LCS.

I think a big part of the problem is that you don't know what your opponents play in solo queue, so bans become much less strategic. The only good strategies then are:

1. Ban the most powerful champs that your team doesn't play. (In practice, this often is just "ban the most powerful champs," but people really should learn what their team plays before randomly banning things.)

2. Ban counters to champions people on your team (usually you) like.

Personally, I wouldn't prefer to ban Gragas under most circumstances since I'd rather just ban the champs that actually have the highest win rates in solo queue (so long as my team doesn't play them). Champions like Amumu, Malzahar, and Heimerdinger are actually bigger threats from that perspective.

Don't ever underestimate the influence that pro players have on most people. Why do you think tele/smite became a thing?

That being said, I don't know why Gragas is on the rise, but Nida's fall was expected. She can't compete in this tanky meta anymore. Her spears are useless with a cougar follow up, and thats death for her at the moment.
